smell_analysis.justification: All diagrams contain visual elements; no empty diagrams were found.
All use cases in the 'Use Case model' diagram are associated with an actor, either directly or via «include» relationships to other use cases connected to actors.
No use cases with redundant names describing the same activity for the same actor were found.
In the 'Diagram: subsystems' (Page 1), the package 'Classifier Register' lists the element 'Product Location' twice in its text content.
No redundant data copies lacking Foreign Key connections were found in the database diagrams. Similar columns (e.g., name, country_code) are properly linked via Foreign Keys.

In the 'Product Functional Subsystem' package on Page 1, the naming form of the listed use cases is inconsistent. One starts with a verb ('Change any product'), while another starts with a noun ('Seller hides product').
All states in the 'State diagram' (Page 4) are reachable from the Start node.
All actions in the activity diagrams (Page 8 and 9) are reachable.
All relationships in class and database diagrams appear to have multiplicity indicators (e.g., 1, 0..*) at both ends.
The 'Use Case model' diagram (Page 7) contains 13 use cases (visual oval elements), which exceeds the threshold of 10 central elements.

On the 'Classifier Register' diagram (Page 6), the class 'Classifier' has 7 visual connection lines (inheritance relationships) to other classes (User Role, Product Location, Product category, Country, Product Status, Category Attribute, Category Attribute Unit), exceeding the limit of 6.
The layout of elements in the diagrams is generally uniform, with no instances of distances exceeding twice the average.
All use cases and activity actions start with active verbs (e.g., View, Search, Set, Insert, Save).
No classes, tables, attributes, or use cases were found with names of 3 characters or less (e.g., 'User', 'Time', 'name' are 4 chars).
All class names start with an uppercase letter and are singular.
All attribute/column names start with a lowercase letter.
All database table names are singular.

No element names were found using Hungarian notation or type prefixes/abbreviations (e.g., tbl_, str). 'app_user' uses a prefix, but it denotes the module/application context rather than the element type (table).
